binding.name: note
binding.literal: Late Antique reddish ware produced in region of Carthage (near Tunis, Tunisia), decorated with rouletting and red slip.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Akaike-machi, Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan.
The Agano kiln was established by Sonkai during the Keicho era (1596-1615).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Belongs to a style of painted pottery found in North Central Syria and South East Anatolia at the beginning of the second millenium BC; characterised by geometric birds, animals and plants, this pottery was found in the earliest levels excavated at Alalakh.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Production Place: France or a more specific placename.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Edo period. Production Place: Arita, Saga Prefecture, Japan.
Porcelain ware of this type was sold through the Imari port, after which it is also sometimes named.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Armorial ware is Chinese porcelain decorated with a coat of arms. It was made for export to Europe or America. Made during the Ming and Qing dynasties, principally 18th and 19th centuries.
See David Sanctuary Howard, Chinese Armorial Porcelain. London 1974.
David Sanctuary Howard, Chinese Armorial Porcelain II. London 2003.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Roman; Production Place: Upper Egypt.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Production Place: Attica, Period Culture: Attic.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Light, whitish or yellowish ware, often with rouletted decoration or applied relief bands, produced at Badorf, Germany, 8th-9thC.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A derivative of Badorf Ware, produced in the Rhineland.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Term used to describe a lime tempered red pottery type made in Bahrain in the late 3rd and early 2nd millennium BC.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
A type of Minoan pottery with plastic effects on the surface resulting from the manipulation of a slip. The technique barbotine is not limited to this period but the ware is only used for pottery from Minoan Crete.
Barbotine technique: Used to describe plastic effects on the surface of a pottery vessel resulting from the manipulation of a slip. The Department of Greece and Rome also use the term as a ware, when the technique is found on Minoan Pottery.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Cypriot; Production Place: Cyprus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Cypriot; Production Place: Cyprus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Base Ring (BR) ware is a distinctive hand-made pottery type from Late Bronze Age Cyprus, one of the three main wares (along with White Slip and Monochrome) that that are found all over the island in this period, particularly from LCII (ca. 1450/1400 BC) onwards when earlier local MC traditions give way to a more uniform ceramic industry. Base Ring ware is characterised by a thin, highly fired, metallic fabric which is black, grey, brown or red-orange in colour (often with a grey core). It probably originated in the north-west of the island, and spread from there over the course of LCI, though it occurs on the south coast at sites such as Maroni within the same period. Major shapes include small juglets with poppy-shaped heads, larger jugs, small storage jars, bowls with wish-bone handles, tankards and specially-shaped pouring vessels (‘rhytons’ or ‘askoi’) in the shape of animals such as bulls. Base Ring ware is also commonly found as exports in surrounding regions of the Eastern Mediterranean; the poppy-shaped juglets in particular may have been valued for their contents, possibly containing medicinal compounds such as opiates.
Three principal varieties of the ware are recognised, which vary in terms of fabrics, techniques, shapes and decorations, though the exact boundary between these groups is debated: Proto-Base Ring ware (PBR) appears at the beginning of the Late Cypriot period in LCIA, somewhat coarser in fabric, and less standardised in shape and technique, than Base Ring I; despite the name, it is debated how much earlier (if at all) PBR is than Base Ring I, or indeed if it is merely a formative stage of this type. Base Ring I (BR I) is characterised in particular by relief decoration and is particularly common during Late Cypriot I but also continuing into Late Cypriot II. Base Ring II (BR II), which is usually less well made than BR I, has white painted decoration on its surface in place of relief, and is generally later (LCIB-II) though the successive numerals do not imply any strict chronological should not be understood as . A wheel-made variety appears towards the end of the Late Cypriot period, under the influence of imported Aegean fabrics and locally made wheel-made wares. Some BR shapes are imitated by Mycenaean potters towards the end of LCII
Bibliography:
P. Åström The Swedish Cyprus Expedition Vol. IV/1C (Lund, 1972), pp. 126-197.
P. Åström ed. The chronology of Base-Ring ware and Bichrome Wheel-made ware (Stockholm, 2001)
S. Vaughan ‘Material and technical classification of Base Ring ware: a new fabric typology’ in J. Barlow, D. Bolger & B. Kling eds. Cypriot ceramics. Reading the prehistoric record (Philadelphia, 1991), pp 119-130.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Cypriot and Iron Age; Production Place: Cyprus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Cypriot and Iron Age; Production Place: Cyprus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
The term can refer to two different types of ware.
The first dates to the end Middle Bronze/ beginning Late Bronze Age and is found and produced in the Levant and Cyprus. [Material Culture: Middle or Late Bronze Age; Production Place: Levant or Production Place: Cyprus.] This version is properly referred to as Bichrome Wheelmade Ware (to distinguish from the later). All examples found on Cyprus to date were produced there. Both Cypriot Bichrome and locally produced is found in Egypt and the Levant.
The second dates to the Iron Age and is Cypriot [Material Culture: Cypriot and Iron Age; Production Place: Cyprus].
If in doubt as to which is referred to, enter all possibilities of Material Culture and Production Place.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Bizen City, Okayama Prefecture, Japan.
Bizen ware is also known as Inbe ware.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a form of decoration on Greek vases, in which figures appear in black with incised details. The Techniques 'painted' and 'incised' are entered. A rare variant, called Silhouette, lacks incision.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term is used for Greek pottery which is covered in a clay slip that turns a glossy black during firing. This is not to be confused with the Technique 'glazed' as used elsewhere for pottery, so the Technique is 'slipped' and not 'glazed'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Iron Age; Production Place: Cyprus or Levant.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Term used to describe at least two distinct classes of pottery in the Middle East. It is most commonly used to describe a variety of cooking pots which were mainly produced in northern Syria and exported into neighbouring regions such as Iraq during the Roman, Byzantine, Sasanian and early Islamic periods. The term has also been used to describe a different class of relatively high-fired Sasanian plainware pottery used in the Pertsian Gulf.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term 'Grey Ware' should be used instead of 'Bucchero' for Greek pottery.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Enter Böttger, Johann Friedrich as the Producer.

binding.name: label
binding.literal: Central Gaulish Rhône Valley Oxidised Ware

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Known after archaeological type-sites in northern Iran where they were found. Approximate date c. 5500-4500 BC.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term greenware is not used for medieval pottery. Only the glaze would be described as green.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Late Bronze Age; Production Place: Levant.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Cizhou-type wares were made in a variety of kilns across Northern China. The most famous of these is Guantai.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Roman; Production Place: Knidos.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Roman; Production Place: Gaul.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to matt finished, Bronze Age, rather than the Roman Cypriot Red Slip Ware (Late Roman D) wares.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Late Predynastic. Production Place: Egypt ???

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Term for burnished generally dark-coloured pottery associated with the later Neolithic (c.6000-4500 BC) in south-eastern Anatolia and northern Syria.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This is a recognised ware term for the Department of Medieval and Later Antiquities. For the Department of Western Asiatic Antiquities, enter this term in the Description field alone, and not in the Ware field.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Roman; Production Place: Syria.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Roman; Production Place: North-West Turkey.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Echizen Province (present-day Niu County in Fukui Prefecture), Japan.
The products of the Echizen potteries are mostly for general household use, unglazed or yellow and red-brown in colour.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Achaemenid, Seleucid, Parthian, Early Islamic. Production Place: southern Iraq.
Term used to describe very thin-walled varieties of unglazed pottery, including distinct types made in southern Iraq. There is no evidence that these traditions are related other than they are very thin-walled.
D. Fleming: "Eggshell ware pottery in Achaemenid Mesopotamia", 'Iraq' 51 (1989), pp. 165-85.
D. Kennet: ' Sasanian and Islamic Pottery from Ras al-Khaimah. Classification, chronology and analysis of trade in the Western Indian Ocean', Oxford: Archaeopress, 2004, p. 61.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a type of 'black glazed' silt ware pottery produced in the Nile Delta in the Ptolemaic period.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Roman; Production Place: Egypt.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Bronze Age. Production Place: Iran.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Achaemenid?, Seleucid, Parthian. Production Place: Iran.
A ware of Iranian origin; believed to be Achaemenid and later in date based on archaeological excavations at Pasargadae and Susa, subsequent excavations on the island of Failaka indicate that it was certainly current in the 3rd century BC and lasted as late as 180 BC.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A type of Early Minoan I-IIA hand-made pottery with a fine grey fabric and smooth surface. Surface often incised with a linear design.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Parthian, Sasanian. Production Place: Iran.
Term used to describe a type of hard-fired reddish-yellow bodied wheel-thrown pottery with black painted designs, made in south-east Iran, and also exported in antiquity to Arabia. The shapes are fine beakers with slightly flaring vertical rims.
D. Kennet: 'Sasanian and Islamic Pottery from Ras al-Khaimah. Classification, chronology and analysis of trade in the Western Indian Ocean', Oxford: Archaeopress, 2004, pp. 61-62.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Italian ware with greenish glaze and applied decoration, possibly made near Rome, late 8th-9thC.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Roman; Production Place: Gaul.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Iron Age; Production Place: Iran.
Term used to describe a type of handmade pottery typically decorated with reddish-brown painted designs resembling kites or veined leaves, and made in the Luristan region of western Iran. This type of pottery dates to about the 9th-8th centuries BC. Before this period, painted pottery was rare in Luristan.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A diagnostic ware of the third millennium in north-eastern Iran and adjacent part of southern Turkmenistan, which may be related to the wider adoption of grey burnished wares across northern Iran in the Early Iron Age, and which have previously been regarded as evidence for the spread of Indo-European speaking peoples.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A type of Middle Helladic wheel-made pottery with a fine grey fabric. It is named after the so-called ‘Treasury of Minyas’ at Orchomenos, where it was first identified, but is produced across mainland Greece in this period.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term 'Grey Ware' should be used instead of 'Bucchero' for Greek pottery.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Grooved Ware is a pottery style current in Britain and Ireland during the Late Neolithic. It is flat based and may be plain or decorated. Where decorated this may be done in a number of ways according to sub-style, for instance grooving, incision, impression, and applied or other plastic decoration all of which are decorative techniques.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Chalcolithic. Production Place: Turkey.
Type of painted pottery named after the type-site of Hacilar which was excavated by James Mellaart.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Hagi and Nagato Cities, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Japan.
Established by the Korean brothers, Ri Shakko and Ri Kei, at Hagi during the Keicho era (1596-1615).

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Kofun period. Production Place: Japan.
Production of this type of bisque began around the beginning of the 4th century.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Late Neolithic. Production Place: Iraq, Syria, Turkey.
Prehistoric pottery ware-type, typically showing fine pale orange/pink fabrics and dark lustrous paint. Decorated with a variety of geometric and naturalistic designs. Halaf is also a chronological and cultural term. Name used interchangeably to describe a period in northern Mesopotamia and a distinctive class of painted pottery. The strong association between this pottery and other distinctive cultural features, including varieties of architecture and portable material culture, has led to the sites where these are found being regarded as part of a distinct culture with an ethnic identity.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Late Islamic. Production Place: Middle East.
This refers specifically to a late and post-medieval type of pottery made widely in the Near East.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Neolithic. Production Place: Iraq.
Prehistoric pottery type from Iraq. Name used interchangeably to describe a period in northern Mesopotamia and a family of coarse handmade pottery, sometimes decorated with incision or paint. The strong association between this pottery and other distinctive cultural features, including varieties of atchitecture and portable material culture, has led to the sites where these are found being regarded as part of a distinct culture with an ethnic identity.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Late Islamic. Production Place: Yemen.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Sasebo City, Nagasaki Prefecture, Japan.
The kiln was called Hirado because it was originally sponsored by the lord of Hirado Province (present Nagasaki Prefecture). This kiln began production during the early Edo period (1603-1868).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Pottery, often lustred, made originally by Islamic craftsmen in southern Spain; in 15thC made mainly in eastern Spain, particularly around Valencia.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Edo period. Production Place: Arita, Saga Prefecture, Japan.
Porcelain ware of this type was sold through the Imari port, after which it is also sometimes named.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: China.
Porcelain ware of this type was sold through the Imari port, after which it is also sometimes named.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Late Bronze Age; Production Place: Levant.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Period Culture = Late Bronze Age. Production Place = Levant.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Late Bronze Age; Production Place: Levant.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Roman, Production Place: Italy

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Ottoman. Production Place: Turkey.
Famous type of glazed porcelain made in Iznik during the 16th and 17th centuries.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Bronze Age. Production Place: Iraq.
c.3000BC-2900BC. A particularly distinctive type of pottery so called because it was first recorded at the site of Jemdet Nasr in central Iraq.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Late Islamic. Production Place: Arabia.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a type of Arita ware of a refined style, with white porcelain and overglaze enamels, produced in Japan from the mid 17thC onwards. See also the term Kakiemon Style ware.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A term traditionally used to describe the pottery of Middle Minoan Crete with a black glossy slip and painted with elaborate designs, usually in white, orange and red. It is named after the Kamares Cave in central Crete where the pottery was first identified, but was produced more widely in Crete.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Saga and Nagasaki, Kyushu, Japan.
Established by immigrant potters from Yi dynasty Korea by the Tensho era (1573-92).

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Bronze Age. Production Place: Iraq, Syria.
The distribution and date of this ware broadly corresponds to the Old Assyrian period in northern Mesopotamia, or c.19th-17th centuries BC. The pottery is typically defined by a variety of medium sized jars and open bowls decorated with horizontal stripes and/or hatched triangles in reddish-brown or dark grey matt paint. Small stamped motifs also occur on some vessels. Simpler varieties of the painted pottery found in western Iran and western Syria are related to Khabur Ware, and may be imitations.
D. Stein: 'Khabur Ware and Nuzi Ware: Their Origin, Relationship, and Significance', Malibu: Undena, 1984.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Early Bronze Age; Production Place: Levant.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Late Islamic. Production Place: Iran or Oman.
Term given by A. Williamson after the town in western Iran where he believed the ware was made. A very similar ware is known from Oman, and named after the modern town of Bahla where it continues to be made. This pottery was also exported to East Africa. It dates to the 15th century and later.
D. Kennet: 'Sasanian and Islamic Pottery from Ras al-Khaimah. Classification, chronology and analysis of trade in Western Indian Ocean', Oxford: Archaeopress, 2004, pp. 42-43.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Toki City, Gifu Prefecture, Japan.
The kiseto (yellow Seto ware) kiln was established during the Tenbun and Eiroku eras (1532-1570), mostly producing table wares covered with a transparent yellow glaze.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Kyoto, Japan.
Originally a specific term for ceramics produced at the kilns to the west of the Kiyomizu-dera temple in Kyoto, it has come to represent Kyoto ceramics.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Ottoman. Production Place: Turkey.
Famous type of glazed porcelain made in Kutahya and Iznik during the 18th and 19th centuries.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan.
Kutani is one of the representative polychrome porcelains of Japan, decorated with dark green, yellow, and purple glazes.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Islamic.
A variety of glazed stonepaste ware found in northern and western Syria. Dates from the late 11th to early 12th century.

binding.name: label
binding.literal: Lincon Market Rasen Fine Reduced Ware

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to Corinthian pottery decorated with patterned motifs. This style is a continuation from the Sub-Geometric style dated from the late 8th-7th centuries BC and lasts into the second half of the 6th century BC.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Parthian. Production Place: Baluchistan.
Type of painted pottery produced in Baluchistan, initially regarded as late Iron Age but now considered to be a Parthian period forerunner of Fine Orange Painted Ware.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Yuan, Ming Dynasty. Production Place: China.
A stoneware covered with a thick green celadon glaze which was widely exported from the Yuan period until the end of the 15th century.
D. Kennet: 'Sasanian and Islamic Pottery from Ras al-Khaimah. Classification, chronology and analysis of trade in Western Indian Ocean', Oxford: Archaeopress, 2004, p. 49.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Magenta ware is a class of pottery household containers (mostly lamp fillers and flasks) in the form of statuettes, dated circa 120BC - 70BC. Beazley so named it because of the purplish-pink pigment preserved on some pieces. The statuettes were made in double moulds and retouched, probably in Campania. The subjects include mythology, the comic stage, genre, fantasy and animals. One piece is signed by Dorotheos.
Reference: R. A. Higgins 'Magenta Ware', in The British Museum Yearbook I (1976), pp.1-32.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The word a medieval Italian form of the island Majorca. Originally used to describe Hispano-Moresque imports, and other lustrewares, which were sometimes shipped through Majorca. Later its meaning has broadened to 'tin-glazed earthenware', particularly that in the style of the Italian Renaissance. See also Majolica, a nineteenth-century term used to describe brightly-coloured relief-moulded lead-glazed earthenware.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Majolica is a nineteenth-century term used to describe brightly-coloured relief-moulded lead-glazed earthenware. See also Maiolica.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: For the Department of Greek and Roman Antiquities, Material Culture: Roman.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Far East.
A class of large storage jar with stoneware body coated with dark brown glaze, which were exported to the Middle East from as early as the 11th century onwards.
D. Kennet: 'Sasanian and Islamic Pottery from Ras al-Khaimah. Classification, chronology and analysis of trade in Western Indian Ocean', Oxford: Archaeopress, 2004, p. 50.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Roman; Production Place: Gaul.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Roman; Production Place: Gaul.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Islamic. Production Place: Iran.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Arts and crafts made by and for the common people.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Korea
A type of ceramic ware originally produced in Yi dynasty Korea around the 15th and 16th centuries.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Cypriot and Late Bronze Age; Production Place: Cyprus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Middle Islamic. Production Place: Iran.
Term used to describe a class of moulded pottery made in Iran and dating to the 12th-13th centuries.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Monochrome painted ware from the Late Bronze Age.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Monochrome painted ware from the Late Bronze Age.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Roman. Production Place: Jordan.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Kan’ei Era. Production Place: Nishimatsuura County, Saga Prefecture, Japan.
A type of porcelain under the patronage of the Nabeshima family, feudal lord of Hizen Province (present-day Saga Prefecture). These wares were never available to the public, but reserved by the Nabeshima family for use as gifts to the government and other feudal lords.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Nagasaki prefecture. The current kiln site is dated from early 1710s to 1820. The kiln produced both stoneware and porcelain. Porcelain in three glazes (sansai) is particularly well known.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A type of lacquer technique named after the temple at Negoro in Kii province.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Romano-British ware (a narrower term of Parchment Ware?).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A type of slipped ware made in the Nene Valley.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Romano-British ware (a narrower term of White Ware?).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Pottery with blue painted decoration (using cobalt-based pigment) fashionable in Egypt in the late 18th and early 19th Dynasties (c.1350-1200 BC).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Late Predynastic. Production Place ?

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production place: Northern Mesopotamia.
c.2750-2500BC
Defined on the basis of the sequence excavated at the site of Tell Mohammed Arab. See Roaf, M. & Killick, R. "A mysterious affair of styles: The Ninevite 5 Pottery of northern Mesopotamia" 'Iraq' Vol. 49, 199-230.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Northern Mesopotamia.
c.3000-2750BC
Defined on the basis of the sequence excavated at the site of Tell Mohammed Arab. See Roaf, M. & Killick, R. "A mysterious affair of styles: The Ninevite 5 Pottery of northern Mesopotamia" 'Iraq' Vol. 49, 199-230.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Mitannian. Production Place: northern Mesopotamia.
Supercedes Khabur Ware, and dates between the 16th and 14th centuries BC. The principal forms are footed goblets but the distinctive use of white paint is also applied to jars in the Khabur tradition and probably marks the point of transition between the two wares.
D. Stein: 'Khabur Ware and Nuzi Ware: Their Origin, Relationship and Significance', Malibu: Undena, 1984.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Regular Jun wares were made at many kilns across Junzhou prefecture (modern Yuzhou or Yuxian) in central Henan from the late Northern Song dynasty (AD 960–1126) until the Ming dynasty (AD 1368–1644). To date, ‘Official’ Jun wares have only been found at one kiln site near the Juntai terrace, inside the north gate of the administrative seat of Yuzhou prefecture. ‘Official’ Jun wares were made in the early Ming period (about AD 1368 to 1435). They are also called ‘Numbered’ Jun because they bear Chinese numbers incised on their bases. These numbers range from one to ten. Their forms are limited to flower pots and their saucers, shallow bulb bowls with studs and bronze-inspired vases. Unlike earlier Song, Jin and Yuan Jun wares, ‘Official’ Jun wares have not been found in tombs but are included in the former palace collections, suggesting they were only made for court use in the Ming dynasty.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Momoyama Period. Production Place: Toki City, Gifu Prefecture, Japan.
Oribe ware is named after the tea master Furuta Oribe (1544-1615) under whose guidance it was produced.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Romano-British ware (a narrower term of Fine Reduced Ware?).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Romano-British ware (a narrower term of Parchment Ware?).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Romano-British ware (a narrower term of Red Slip Ware?).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Romano-British ware (a narrower term of White Slip Ware?).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Romano-British ware (a narrower term of White Ware?).

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Late Assyrian. Production Place: northern Mesopotamia.
Type of fine unglazed pottery, often with deliberate dimpled walls, which is typical of 9th-7th century BC sites across northern Mesopotamia.
P.S. Rawson: "Palace Wares from Nimrud: technical observations on selected examples", 'Iraq' 16 (1954), pp.168-72.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Term for pottery burnished with a darker more lustrous pattern on lighter background. Patterns are typically geometric. Associated with the later Neolithic (c. 6000-4500 BC) in south-eastern Anatolia and northern Syria.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Roman; Production Place: Phocaea.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Light buff or yellowish ware with red-slipped, comma-like strokes, or linear decoration, produced at Pingsdorf, Germany, 10th-12thC.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A derivative of Pingsdorf Ware, produced in Limburg, Netherlands, c12th-13thC.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Roman; Production Place: Pontus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Ceramic with a blue-white glaze, made at Jingdezhen and other Chinese kiln sites.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Kyoto, Japan.
Raku ware refers to ceramic produced by the Raku family, which is first formed by hand and then fired in temperatures from 700˚C to 1000˚C. The term sometimes refers to all pottery made by this process.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Islamic. Production Place: Syria.
Term used to describe a family of glazed stonepaste wares, particularly lustre painted, black underpainted turquoise glazed and relief moulded types. Dates to the 12th and 13th centuries and produced in Syria. They are known after the Medieval city-site of Raqqa where most, but probably not all, were produced.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term refers to a form of decoration on Greek vases, in which figures appear in red, with slip-painted background and details. The Technique entered is 'painted'.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Late Bronze Age; Production Place: PAM?

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Cypriot and to Early and Middle Bronze Age and the very beginning of the Late Bronze Age; Production Place: Cyprus. NB. Do not enter this term for Roman Red Slip Ware.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Cypriot and either Middle Bronze Age or - less frequently - the beginning of the Late Bronze Age; Production Place: Cyprus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Cypriot and either Middle Bronze Age or - less frequently - the beginning of the Late Bronze Age; Production Place: Cyprus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: This term refers to Roman Cypriot Red Slip Ware (Late Roman D), rather than the matt finished, Bronze Age wares.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Term used within northern Iraq to describe a distinctive, usually unglazed, type of pottery associated with Late Ottoman sites and possibly dating to the 18th-19th centuries.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Chalcolithic, Early Islamic. Production Place: Iraq.
For the Department of the Middle East, this usually refers to a particular pottery type produced in Mesopotamia c.6000-5500 BC. But in the Department of Asia the same term, deriving from the same site name, is used for a particular type of glazed pottery made in Iraq in the 9th century AD.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Aichi Prefecture, Japan.
The Sanage kiln has produced pottery from the protohistoric period.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Edo Period. Production Place: Hyogo Prefecture, Japan.
A type of ceramic ware produced in Hyogo Prefecture.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Keicho Era. Production Place: Kagoshima Prefecture, Japan.
The Satsuma kilns were established by immigrant potters from Yi dynasty Korea.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Early Dynastic; Production Place: Mesopotamia.
A style of red and black painted pottery decorated with haematite or vermilion (cinnabar) and soot. The distribution of this pottery is largely limited to the Diyala and Hamrin river basins of east central Iraq.

binding.name: label
binding.literal: Scottish East Coast White Gritty Ware

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Seto City, Aichi Prefecture, Japan.
The Seto kiln began producing glazed pottery from the mid-Heian period (794-1195).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Term used to describe a widespread type of glazed pottery whereby the surface was covered with a fine pale slip which was incised through to the underlying body and then covered with a transparent glaze, and often highlighted with splashes of coloured glaze. It is also known in the literature as graffito or sgraffito ware.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Shigaraki Town, Shiga Prefecture, Japan.
Shigaraki kilns produced unglazed earthenware, with a characteristic reddish-brown body.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Muromachi Period. Production Place: Gifu Prefecture, Japan.
A type of mino ware.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Shufu (樞府 meaning ‘Privy Council’) are porcelains marked shufu, made at Jingdezhen in the Yuan dynasty (early 14thC).

binding.name: note
binding.literal: The term ‘Silhouette’ refers to a form of decoration found on Corinthian and Attic figured vases. It is a variant, or sub-category, of the more common Black-Figure decoration, in which figures are rendered in black silhouette and then incised. ‘Silhouette’ figures, however, are merely rendered in silhouette without any incised detail. In some instances, both forms of decoration are also found on the same vessel.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Roman; Production Place: Spain.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Kofun Period. Production Place: Japan.
A type of unglazed pottery made in ancient Japan.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Islamic. Production Place: Iran.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Nogata and Iizuka Cities, Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan.
Established by immigrant potters from Yi dynasty Korea.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Middle Bronze Age; Production Place: Egypt or Levant.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Islamic. Production Place: Syria.
Glazed ware on a frit body, related to Raqqa Ware.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Islamic. Production Place: Syria.
A variety of glazed stonepaste ware found in northern Syria and dating to the 12th and 13th centuries.
V. Porter & O. Watson, "Tell Minis Wares", 'Syria and Iran: Three Studies in Medieval Ceramics' (J. Allan & C. Roberts, eds) pp. 175-248. Oxford: OUP; Oxford Studies in Islamic Art, vol.4.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Roman; Production Place: Gaul.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Roman; Production Place: Gaul.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Cream paste; red slip on upper surface.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Light paste; red slip covers whole vessel.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Orange paste; red slip on the upper surface.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Very fine-grained paste, smooth in fracture; highly-polished self-coloured surface. Used only for beakers.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: In the Department of Greek and Roman Antiquities, this refers to Roman ware; Material Culture: Roman.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Edo Period. Production Place: Tobe Town, Ehime Prefecture, Japan.
Porcelain made of the material from the basin of the river Tobe.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Production Place: Chita peninsula, Aichi Prefecture, Japan.
A type of pottery ware produced across the Chita peninsula in Aichi Prefecture.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Late Bronze Age. Production Place western Turkey.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A distinctive type of painted pottery produced in the Urmia basin of north-west Iran and found at sites such as Haftavan Tepe (level VI) and Geoy Tepe. It dates to between about 1900 and 1400 BC. See Michael R. Edwards, "The Pottery of Haftavan VIB (Urmia Ware)", 'Iran' 19 (1981), pp. 101-140.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A characteristic type of Early Minoan IIB hand-made pottery with a red and black mottled surface resulting from oxidation/reduction of the slip. It is named after Vasiliki in East Crete, but production was not limited to this site.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: East Greek; Production Place: Rhodes.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Iron Age; Production Place: Iran.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Cypriot and either Middle Bronze Age or Late Bronze Age; Production Place: Cyprus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A recognised Ware term for end of Middle Bronze Age Cyprus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Cypriot and Middle Bronze Age; Production Place: Cyprus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: A recognised Ware term for end of Middle Bronze Age Cyprus and beginning of the Late Bronze Age..

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Cypriot and Late Bronze Age; Production Place: Cyprus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Cypriot and Late Bronze Age; Production Place: Cyprus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Cypriot and Late Bronze Age; Production Place: Cyprus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Cypriot and Late Bronze Age; Production Place: Cyprus.

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
White Slip (WS) ware is a distinctive hand-made pottery type from Late Bronze Age Cyprus, one of the three main wares (along with Base Ring and Monochrome) that that are found all over the island in this period, particularly from LCII (ca. 1450/1400 BC) onwards when earlier local MC traditions give way to a more uniform ceramic industry. All WS vessels are hand-made from fairly fine, but sometimes gritty, clay, over which is put a thick white, cream or buff slip, fired to temperatures in excess of 1000° C. The surface is decorated in dark (usually black, brown or red) paint: common motifs include parallel lines, hatched bands, ladders, rows of lozenges, wavy lines, and lines of dots. Rare examples of pictorial decoration are also attested.
Major shapes include hemispherical bowls with wish-bone handles (‘milk bowls’), small juglets similar in form to Base Ring poppy-shaped juglets, and larger jugs and ‘craters’ (that is, bowls), and bottles. The shapes suggest that WS wares were mostly used for eating and drinking rather than storage or cooking. WS wares were exported to the surrounding regions of the Eastern and Central Mediterranean in large quantities.
This ware is commonly divided into categories according to technique, shape and decoration: Proto White Slip is a formative phase owing much to older Middle Cypriot White Painted wares; White Slip I marks the technical and artistic peak of the fabric type; White Slip IIA seems to be a regional variant of WS I; White Slip II. The latter type is more standardised and mass produced than WS I, showing a marked decline in quality towards the end of the ware’s life in LCIIC-IIIA (13th and 12th centuries BC), sometimes called White Slip Late in the archaeological literature. The chronology of the WS continues to be problematic, as few stratified sequences exist sowing the full development of the ware.
M. Popham ‘White Slip ware’ in P. Åström The Swedish Cyprus Expedition Vol. IV/1C (Lund, 1972), pp. 431-471.
V. Karageorghis ed. The White Slip ware of Late Bronze Age Cyprus (Vienna, 2001)

binding.name: note
binding.literal:
Material Culture: Edo Period. Production Place: Yatsushiro City, Japan.
Established by an immigrant Korean potter in 1633 at the request of the lord of Higo Province.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: Material Culture: Early Bronze Age; Production Place: Anatolia.

binding.name: note
binding.literal: These heavily-potted and crudely-painted porcelains were made for export at various kilns, mostly located in the Chinese coastal province of Fujian. Before 1994, these porcelains were called ‘Swatow’ wares after an old Dutch transliteration of Shantou, a port in northern Guangong province which was mistakenly connected with them. They were traded to countries in Southeast Asia such as Indonesia, the Phillipines and Malaysia as well as to Japan and Holland. They are characterised by coarse sandy bases and were made with underglaze blue, overglaze enamel and slip decoration on a single coloured ground.
